knowledge_graph.title: Affordable Care Act
knowledge_graph.description: The Affordable Care Act, formally known as the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and informally as Obamacare, is a landmark U.S. federal statute enacted by the 111th United States Congress and signed into law by President Barack Obama on March 23, 2010.

related_questions.question: What is the Affordable Care Act in simple terms?
related_questions.snippet: The Affordable Care Act (ACA) is a comprehensive reform law, enacted in 2010, that increases health insurance coverage for the uninsured and implements reforms to the health insurance market. This includes many provisions that are consistent with AMA policy and holds the potential for a better health care system.
related_questions.title: Understanding the Affordable Care Act | What is the ACA| AMA

related_questions.question: What are the pros and cons of the Affordable Care Act?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Expanded Coverage and Accessibility: The ACA significantly increased the number of Americans with health insurance through the expansion of Medicaid and the creation of health insurance marketplaces.
Protection for Pre-existing Conditions: Insurance companies can no longer deny coverage or charge higher premiums based on pre-existing health conditions.
Improved Access to Preventative Care: The ACA mandates coverage for preventative services like check-ups and screenings, encouraging early detection and management of health issues.
Cost-Sharing Reductions: Subsidies are available to help lower-income individuals and families afford premiums and out-of-pocket costs in the marketplaces.
Young Adult Coverage: Young adults can often stay on their parents' insurance plans until age 26.

Rising Premiums and Deductibles: . Opens in new tabWhile subsidies help some, many individuals and families still face high premiums and deductibles, particularly those who do not qualify for subsidies.
Potential for Limited Provider Choice: . Opens in new tabSome regions have reported limited provider networks in ACA plans, making it harder to find doctors within a desired network.
Complexity of the Insurance Market: . Opens in new tabNavigating the health insurance marketplaces and understanding the different plan options can be challenging for many individuals.
Impact on Small Businesses: . Opens in new tabSome small businesses have faced challenges related to the ACA's employer mandate and increased costs.

Individual Mandate Penalties: . Opens in new tabThe ACA initially included a penalty for individuals who did not obtain health insurance, which was later eliminated, but some still view this as a negative aspect.

related_questions.question: What is the difference between Obamacare and the Affordable Care Act?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Expanding Medicaid eligibility: . Opens in new tabMore low-income individuals and families can now qualify for Medicaid.
Creating the Health Insurance Marketplace: . Opens in new tabThis online platform allows individuals and families to shop for and compare health insurance plans.
Preventing insurance companies from denying coverage for pre-existing conditions: . Opens in new tabThis ensures that people with pre-existing conditions can get the coverage they need.
Requiring insurers to cover a list of essential health benefits: . Opens in new tabThis ensures that plans cover important services like doctor visits, hospitalization, and prescription drugs.

related_questions.question: What is the highest income to qualify for ACA?
related_questions.snippet: The income limits for Obamacare in 2025 are between $15,060 (minimum) and $60,240 (maximum) for an individual. For a couple, the income limits to qualify for Obamacare are between $20,440 and $81,760. For a family of three, the minimum is $25,820 and the maximum is $103,280.
related_questions.title: ▷ Obamacare Income Limits 2025 Chart - Dulcinea Insurance

text_blocks.snippet: The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, is a comprehensive healthcare reform law enacted in 2010. Its main goals are to make affordable health insurance accessible to more people, expand Medicaid coverage, and support innovative healthcare delivery methods.
snippet_highlighted_words: a comprehensive healthcare reform law enacted in 2010

list.title: Increased Access to Coverage:
list.snippet: The ACA aimed to significantly reduce the number of uninsured Americans. It achieved this through various mechanisms, including expanding Medicaid eligibility and creating health insurance marketplaces (also known as exchanges).

list.title: Affordable Coverage:
list.snippet: The ACA provides financial assistance (subsidies) to help individuals and families afford health insurance premiums and cost-sharing (like deductibles and co-pays).

list.title: Consumer Protections:
list.snippet: The ACA includes provisions to protect consumers from insurance company practices that were previously problematic, such as denying coverage based on pre-existing conditions, charging women more than men, and imposing lifetime limits on coverage.

list.title: Essential Health Benefits:
list.snippet: The ACA requires that all health insurance plans sold on the exchanges and many employer-sponsored plans cover a set of essential health benefits, including preventative services, hospitalization, prescription drugs, and mental health services.

list.title: Medicaid Expansion:
list.snippet: The ACA allowed states to expand Medicaid eligibility to individuals and families with incomes up to 138% of the federal poverty level.

list.title: Health Insurance Marketplaces:
list.snippet: The ACA established online marketplaces where individuals and small businesses can shop for and compare health insurance plans. These marketplaces offer a range of plans categorized by metal tiers (bronze, silver, gold, and platinum) based on cost and coverage levels.

list.title: Individual Mandate:
list.snippet: While the individual mandate (requiring individuals to have health insurance or pay a penalty) was eliminated in 2017, the ACA continues to provide subsidies and protections for those who enroll in plans through the marketplaces.
The ACA has significantly reduced the number of uninsured Americans, with the uninsured rate reaching a record low in 2023.
Millions of people have gained access to affordable health insurance through the ACA's expansion of Medicaid and the creation of the health insurance marketplaces.
The ACA has led to increased access to preventative care, mental health services, and prescription drugs.
The ACA has also improved the quality of care for those with private insurance by requiring coverage of essential health benefits and implementing consumer protections.

key_moments.title: The ACA produced widespread gains in health coverage.
Over 20 million people gained insurance including individuals who can stay on their parents' plan until they're 26.
The law prevents insurers from setting annual or lifetime limits on spending.
The ACA focuses on preventive care by ensuring plans cover the cost of recommended preventive services.
The ACA improves health care for women and children.
The law prevents insurers from charging women higher premiums than men.
5 The Affordable Care Act is better than ever.
Many premiums will decrease, on average, by $50 per person and $85 per policy per month.
